conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, we need to analyze the motion of the particle based on the given acceleration-time graph.
The graph shows that the acceleration a varies with time t in a piecewise linear manner.
From t = 0 to t = t0/2, the acceleration increases linearly from 0 to a0.
From t = t0/2 to t = t0, the acceleration decreases linearly from a0 to 0.
From t = t0 to t = 3t0/2, the acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -a0.
From t = 3t0/2 to t = 2t0, the acceleration increases linearly from -a0 to 0.

premise: The velocity v is the integral of the acceleration a.
conclusion: From t = 0 to t = t0/2, v(t) = (a0/t0) t^2. At t = t0/2, v = (a0 t0)/4.

premise: From t = t0/2 to t = t0, v(t) = a0 t - (a0/t0) t^2. At t = t0, v = 0.
conclusion: The velocity becomes zero at t = t0.
The velocity is negative at t = 3t0/2.
The velocity becomes zero again at t = 2t0.

premise: The position x is the integral of the velocity v.

conclusion: The position continues to increase until t = t0.

premise: The particle always moves in the positive direction until t = 2t0.
conclusion: At t = 2t0, the particle is farthest from the starting point.
